content: It's too difficult for reverse mode.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle that took me exactly 5 minutes to solve. I enjoyed it.

Hi!

Is it a good idea to add a test with N = 100?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Enjoyed having to create an "isprime" function for a simple problem

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Approved good contribution.

Hello!
A thought about context: it brained me a bit before I understand games' prices in the store aren't necessary, as "most expensive game you can afford" means "the maximum amount you can spend". If intended, think about that: for some of us English is not our born language, so, even if we understand words, we may have trouble to play with them. Maybe a more straightforward output description can be better.

Goal
* Please format "N" as a [[variable]].

Input
* Please add line numbers to the front of the descriptions in <<bold>>, i.e. <<Line 1>> and <<Line 2>>.

* Please format "N", "x1", "x2", "xN" as [[variables]].

Constraints
* Please change "X" to "[[x1]] [[x2]] … [[xN]]" for consistency.

* Please format "N" as a [[variable]].

Thanks.

Thanks for the examples. Wasn't sure how to format at first.
Fixed it!

Added clarifying statements: 
You arrive at the magical prime store, where they have infinite games: for each positive number, they have at least one game with that price. So, as long as your budget is greater than 0, you can spend it all on a single game.
Notes:
The "most expensive game you can afford" means "the maximum amount you can spend".
Doesn't really matter since each coin is treated independently, so there is no "slow" algorithm we're trying to make sure doesn't pass.

Do you suggest I remove it? or improve with test cases?
I think it's easy after a few checks to see it's adding some elements but not all. 
It think test 4,5,6 help to have the "eureka" thought about prime number.
It's on the difficult side but reverse are always harder.

If you have some good test cases to suggest, I can add them :)

Also curious. Since it's already accepted, how did you make a comment?
Did you find it in a reverse clash?

Yes, I did it in reverse mode, and was the winner with 50%, while everyone else were at 0%.

Checking a clash to reverse it is usually impossible if it has a statement or title that gives a clue, in these cases we weren't in the same conditions as the players.

As I've already read the statement, I'm not sure I can give you a “eureka” test case. 

For reverse mode, one way of giving a clue is to change the "Write answer" of the stub by the title of the clash or another clue.

Good idea. Changed it to
write Answer (x may be prime)
Maybe the Note is now no more necessary as you precise there is always a game available for any possible price. Sorry to bore you :)

No worries!

There are still some "N"s to format: one in Goal section, and two in Input section.

Thanks.

I did format those but thought it was more distracting than helpful so undid it. 
But I will follow your advice. Fixed.
